This dish is a perfect combination of seafood goodness, smoky aromas, and rich, creamy sauce that will leave your taste buds longing for more.

ingredients.Name: chipotle powder (adjust to taste for spiciness)
dried cherry powder (grind dried cherries to a fine powder)

directions.Direction: For The Chipotle Rub

Prepare the Cherry Chipotle Rub: In a small bowl, combine all the rub ingredients—brown sugar, smoked paprika, chipotle powder, garlic powder, onion powder, salt, black pepper, dried thyme, ground coriander, ground cinnamon, ground cloves, and dried cherry powder. Mix well to create a flavorful rub.
For the Steak
Preparing the Tomahawk Steak: Remove the tomahawk steak from the refrigerator and let it sit at room temperature for about 30-60 minutes before cooking. This allows the meat to cook more evenly.

Preheat the Smoker: While the steak is coming to room temperature, preheat your smoker to a temperature of around 225°F. Add cherry wood chips to the smoker box or directly to the coals for that wonderful cherry smoke flavor.
Apply the Cherry Chipotle Rub: Pat the tomahawk steak dry with paper towels. Then generously coat all sides of the steak with the Cherry Chipotle Rub, pressing it into the meat to ensure it adheres.

Smoking the Steak: Once the smoker is ready, place the tomahawk steak on the grates, ensuring it is not too close to the heat source. Close the smoker lid and allow the steak to smoke for approximately 1.5 to 2 hours or until the internal temperature reaches around 120-125°F for medium-rare. Use a meat thermometer to check the internal temperature.

Searing the Steak: When the tomahawk steak is almost at the desired internal temperature, preheat a grill or cast-iron skillet over high heat. You can also use a blowtorch to sear the edges. Sear the steak for 1-2 minutes per side or until you achieve a beautiful crust and a crispy finish.

Resting and Serving: Once the steak reaches the desired doneness and is nicely seared, remove it from the heat and let it rest for 10-15 minutes to allow the juices to redistribute within the meat. After resting, carve and serve.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Cherry Chipotle Tomahawk Steak
Description: The Smoked Cherry Chipotle Tomahawk Steak is the epitome of indulgence and flavor. This impressive, thick-cut ribeye steak, still attached to the bone, provides a stunning presentation that will have everyone's mouth watering. The smoking process infuses the meat with a subtle, sweet cherry aroma, perfectly complementing the bold flavors of the chipotle rub.

ingredients.Name: bone broth (from the smoked beef shank)

directions.Direction: Preheat your smoker to 225°F.
For the Beef Shank

Smoking the Beef Shank:Cover the bone of the beef shank with tin foil to prevent charring during the long smoking process. Rub the beef shank with olive oil, salt, and pepper on all sides.Place the beef shank on the smoker grates, close the lid, and smoke it at 225°F (107°C) for approximately 14 hours or until the meat is tender and easily pulls away from the bone.
For the Pie Filling

Making the Filling: In a pot, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the finely chopped onion and sauté until translucent. Pour in the bone broth, frozen peas, chopped carrots, and yellow squash. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Once the smoked beef shank is done, remove it from the smoker, and set it aside. Remove the tin foil from the bone and add the bone along with the smoked beef shank meat to the pot. Simmer the filling until it reaches a thick and hearty consistency. Adjust seasoning if needed.
For The Pie Crust

Preparing the Pie Crust: In a large bowl, combine the all-purpose flour and salt. Add the cold, cubed butter and use a pastry cutter or your hands to mix until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Gradually add ice-cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, until the dough comes together. Divide the dough into two equal parts and shape each into a disc. Wrap the dough discs in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
Preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C).

Assembling the Beef Shank Pie: Take one of the chilled pie crust discs and roll it out on a floured surface to fit the size of your springform cake pan. Line the springform cake pan with the rolled-out pie crust, making sure it covers the bottom and sides of the pan. Stand the smoked beef shank bone in the center of the pan. Surround the standing bone with the prepared filling mixture, ensuring it evenly fills the space around the bone. Roll out the second pie crust disc and use it to cover the top of the pie. Seal the edges by pressing the top and bottom crusts together. Brush the top of the pie with a beaten egg to give it a shiny finish.

Baking the Beef Shank Pie: Place the assembled pie on a baking sheet to catch any drips during baking. Bake the pie in the preheated oven for about 45 minutes to 1 hour, or until the crust is golden brown and the filling is hot and bubbling. Once baked, let the pie cool for a few minutes before carefully removing the springform cake pan.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Thor's Hammer Beef Shank Pie
Description:
The Smoked Bone-In Beef Shank Pie is a savory and hearty dish that boasts the rich flavors of a slowly smoked beef shank. The bone-in beef shank is first tenderized to perfection through a 14-hour smoking process, resulting in succulent, melt-in-your-mouth meat. To prevent charring, the bone is thoughtfully covered in tin foil, ensuring the meat remains moist and smoky.

The Thor's Hammer visual effect takes this pie to the next level, adding a creative and eye-catching element to the dish. As you slice into the pie, the bone from the smoked beef shank stands proudly in the center, resembling the iconic Mjölnir, Thor's legendary hammer. This striking centerpiece not only captures attention but also reinforces the incredible taste and presentation of this exceptional dish.

The flavorful filling, crafted from beef drippings, bone broth, onions, frozen peas, carrots, and yellow squash, further enhances the overall taste and texture of the pie. Encased in a flaky, golden-brown pie crust, the pie delivers a delightful blend of smoky beef, wholesome vegetables, and comforting aromas.

With each bite, you'll savor the smoky essence of the beef, the heartiness of the filling, and the marvel of the Thor's Hammer visual effect, making this Smoked Bone-In Beef Shank Pie an unforgettable culinary experience fit for a feast or a special occasion.

ingredients.Name: cayenne pepper (adjust to your spice preference)

directions.Direction: Preheat your grill or smoker to 275°F (135°C).
Peel the onions and slice them into thick rings, about 1/2 inch (1.2 cm) in thickness. Separate the rings and set aside the smaller inner rings.
In a mixing bowl, combine the breakfast sausage, shredded cheddar cheese, salt, and pepper. Mix well until everything is evenly combined.
Take one of the larger onion rings and fill the center with the sausage and cheese mixture, pressing it down gently to ensure it's packed inside.
Take one of the smaller onion rings and place it inside the larger onion ring, on top of the sausage and cheese mixture. This creates the donut shape.
Wrap the stuffed onion rings with 2-3 slices of bacon, securing them in place with wooden toothpicks.
In a small bowl, mix together the ingredients for the seasoning rub: paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, and cayenne pepper.
Sprinkle the seasoning rub evenly over the bacon-wrapped onion rings.
Place the stuffed and seasoned onion rings on the grill or smoker and cook at 275°F (135°C) for about 2 hours, or until the bacon is crispy and the onions are tender.
Carefully remove the toothpicks before serving.

While the onion rings are finished on the smoker put them onto a flat-top grill and prepare the eggs. Crack an egg into the center of each bacon-wrapped onion ring, being careful not to break the yolk.
Continue cooking on the grill for an additional 5-7 minutes, or until the egg whites are fully set but the yolks are still slightly runny.
Remove the onion ring "bacon donuts" with the cooked eggs from the grill and serve immediately.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Breakfast Carnivore Donuts
Description: These indulgent and savory bacon onion rings are a unique twist on the classic recipe. Thick onion slices are filled with a delicious mixture of breakfast sausage and cheddar cheese, then nested with a smaller onion slice to create a donut shape. The whole creation is wrapped in bacon and seasoned with a mouthwatering rub, giving it a bacon-donut appearance. After a slow bake on the grill, the stuffed onion rings are topped with a perfectly cooked egg, making for a sumptuous and satisfying breakfast dish that will leave your taste buds delighted.

directions.Direction: For the Beef Cheeks

Prepare the Beef Cheeks: In a bowl, combine soy sauce, brown sugar, minced garlic, salt, and black pepper to create the marinade. Rub the marinade all over the beef cheeks, ensuring they are evenly coated. Let them marinate for at least 1 hour in the refrigerator.
Prepare the Smoker: Preheat your smoker to 225°F (107°C).

Smoking the Beef Cheeks: Place the marinated beef cheeks directly on the smoker grates. Smoke the beef cheeks low and slow, unwrapped, for about 3 to 4 hours or until they have developed a nice bark on the outside.

Wrapping the Beef Cheeks: Remove the beef cheeks from the smoker and place each one on a piece of aluminum foil. Add a tablespoon of butter and a splash of apple cider vinegar to each beef cheek. Wrap the beef cheeks tightly in the foil. Place the wrapped beef cheeks back on the smoker and continue cooking for another hour.
For the Bao Buns

Prepare the Bao Buns: In a mixing bowl, combine warm water, milk, and vegetable oil. Sprinkle the yeast over the liquid mixture and let it sit for about 5 minutes until foamy. In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, salt, and baking powder. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until a dough forms. Knead the dough for about 5 minutes until it becomes smooth and elastic. Place the dough in a greased bowl, cover it with a damp cloth, and let it rise in a warm place for about 1 hour or until it doubles in size.

Shaping and Steaming the Bao Buns: After the dough has risen, punch it down and roll it out flat on a floured surface to a thickness of about 1/4 inch. Use a small bowl or a round cutter to cut out circles from the dough. Lightly brush the tops of the circles with oil or melted butter. Fold each circle in half and place it on a small piece of parchment paper. Set up a steamer and steam the buns for about 8-10 minutes until they become soft and fluffy.
For the Finished Product

Assembling the Beef Cheek Bao: Once the beef cheeks are tender and juicy, remove them from the smoker and let them rest for a few minutes before slicing. Slice the beef cheeks into thin strips. Open the steamed buns and spread some chili garlic sauce on the inside of each one. Place a few slices of the smoked beef cheeks on the sauce. Top with pickled red onions and a drizzle of kewpie mayo. Serve immediately and enjoy your delicious Smoked Beef Cheek Bao with Homemade Buns!

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Beef Cheek Bao Buns
Description: This dish features succulent, tender beef cheeks marinated in a savory soy sauce blend with hints of garlic and sweetness from brown sugar. The beef cheeks are slow-cooked on a smoker to perfection, resulting in a smoky and flavorful filling for the bao buns. The homemade bao buns are soft, fluffy, and slightly sweet, making them the perfect vessel to hold the mouthwatering smoked beef cheeks.

ingredients.Name: pork spice seasoning (store bought or homemade)
BBQ rub or your favorite seasoning blend (optional, for extra flavor)

directions.Direction: Preheat your smoker to 275°F using your preferred smoking wood chips or pellets for flavor (applewood or hickory work well).

Lay out a sheet of plastic wrap on a clean surface or cutting board. Arrange the bacon slices side by side horizontally on the plastic wrap, slightly overlapping each other to create a rectangular bacon weave. Make sure the weave is large enough to accommodate the breakfast sausage. Coat the bacon in your favorite pork seasoning.
With a sheet of parchment paper on top of the sausage mixture. Use a rolling pin or your hands to flatten and spread the sausage into a thin, rectangular sheet that fits inside the bacon weave.
Carefully remove the parchment paper from the sausage and place the sausage sheet onto the center of the bacon weave.
In a separate bowl, whisk the eggs until well beaten. Scramble the eggs in a lightly greased skillet over medium heat until they are cooked but still slightly moist. Remove from the heat.
Spread the scrambled eggs evenly over the breakfast sausage layer.
Sprinkle the shredded cheddar cheese over the eggs.
If desired, sprinkle a light layer of BBQ rub or your favorite seasoning blend over the cheese for added flavor.
Using the plastic wrap as a guide, carefully lift and roll the bacon and sausage layers into a log shape. Make sure to tuck in any loose edges to prevent the filling from spilling out during smoking.
Place the breakfast log directly onto the smoker grate and close the lid.
Smoke the breakfast log at 275°F for approximately 2 to 2.5 hours or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F  when measured with a meat thermometer.
Once the breakfast log reaches the desired internal temperature, remove it from the smoker and let it rest for a few minutes before slicing.
Slice the smoked breakfast log into rounds and serve warm. Enjoy this delicious and savory breakfast treat!

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Smoked Breakfast Log
Description: The smoked breakfast log is a flavorful and hearty breakfast dish made by weaving thick-cut bacon together to create a rectangular base. Inside the bacon weave, a layer of breakfast sausage seasoned with pork spice is flattened to form a thin sheet. Scrambled eggs are then added to the center of the sausage layer, followed by a generous sprinkling of shredded cheddar cheese. The entire assembly is carefully rolled into a log shape, making sure all the delicious fillings are enclosed within the bacon weave. This log is then smoked at a low temperature until the internal temperature reaches 165°F, infusing all the flavors and textures together. The result is a savory, smoky, and indulgent breakfast treat that combines the smokiness of bacon, the richness of sausage and eggs, and the creaminess of melted cheese into a mouthwatering log that's perfect for sharing with friends and family.

ingredients.Name: Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

directions.Direction: Prepare the Bone Marrow: Preheat your smoker to 300°F (150°C). Place the bone marrow bones on the smoker grate and smoke them for an hour, allowing the rich smoky flavor to infuse into the marrow.

Make the Chimichurri Sauce: In a medium-sized bowl, combine the finely chopped parsley, minced garlic, finely chopped shallot, and chili flakes. Add the red wine vinegar and slowly drizzle in the extra-virgin olive oil while whisking continuously until well combined. Season the chimichurri sauce with salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Adjust the seasonings according to your preference for acidity and spiciness.

Brulée the Bone Marrow: Once the bone marrow has been smoked for an hour, remove the bones from the smoker and let them rest for a few minutes until they are cool enough to handle. Sprinkle a thin, even layer of granulated sugar over the exposed marrow surface of each bone. Use a culinary torch to caramelize the sugar until it forms a golden crust on top of the bone marrow. The sugar will create a sweet and slightly crunchy layer.

Assemble and Serve: Place the bruléed bone marrow bones on a serving platter. Spoon the prepared chimichurri sauce generously over each bone, allowing it to seep into the crevices of the bone marrow. Serve the bone marrow brulée immediately alongside warm crusty bread for spreading and scooping the delicious mixture.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Bone Marrow Brulée
Description: Smoked Bone Marrow Brulée with Chimichurri is a tantalizing and sophisticated dish that combines the luxurious flavors of bone marrow with a smoky, caramelized crust. The bone marrow is first delicately smoked to infuse it with a rich, smoky essence. A sprinkle of sugar on top of the marrow is then carefully torched to create a sweet and crispy brulée crust. To enhance the dish's taste and freshness, a zesty chimichurri sauce is prepared with parsley, garlic, shallot, chili flakes, red wine vinegar, and olive oil. This vibrant and herbaceous sauce complements the decadence of the bone marrow, adding a burst of flavors. Served on warm, crusty bread, this elegant appetizer promises to delight your taste buds and impress your guests with its unique blend of textures and tastes.

ingredients.Name: cayenne pepper (adjust to your spice preference)
For the bone marrow and bacon butter:
strips of cooked bacon, finely chopped

directions.Direction: Prepare the Beef Rub: In a small bowl, mix all the beef rub ingredients until well combined. Set aside.

Coat the Tri-Tip Steak: Pat the tri-tip steak dry with paper towels. Generously coat all sides of the steak with the beef rub mixture. Make sure to press the rub into the meat to ensure it adheres well. Place the seasoned steak in a large Ziploc bag or cover it with plastic wrap and refrigerate it for at least 4 hours or overnight to allow the flavors to penetrate the meat.

Cook the Bone Marrow: Preheat your oven to 275°F (135°C). Place the bone marrow bones on a grilling tray or a baking sheet with a rim to catch any drippings. Cook the bone marrow for about an hour until it becomes tender and starts to release its flavorful juices.

Prepare the Bacon Butter: In a small mixing bowl, combine the softened butter, finely chopped bacon, salt, and pepper. Mix well until the bacon is evenly distributed throughout the butter. Remove the bone marrow from the oven and let it cool slightly. Using a small spoon or knife, scoop the cooked marrow out of the bones and add it to the bacon-butter mixture. Mix everything together until well combined. This will create delicious bone marrow and bacon butter.

Smoke the Tri-Tip Steak: Preheat your smoker to 250°F (121°C). If using a charcoal or wood smoker, add your preferred smoking wood (hickory or oak work well with beef) to the coals for a nice smoky flavor.

Smother the Tri-Tip with Bone Marrow and Bacon Butter: Take the tri-tip out of the fridge and let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes before smoking. Spread a generous amount of the bone marrow and bacon butter all over the tri-tip, ensuring it covers the entire surface.

Smoke the Tri-Tip: Place the butter-coated tri-tip on a grilling tray or directly on the smoker grates. Insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the steak. Smoke the tri-tip until the internal temperature reaches 130°F (54°C) for medium-rare doneness. This should take approximately 1.5 to 2 hours, depending on the thickness of the steak.
Rest and Serve: Once the tri-tip has reached the desired internal temperature, remove it from the smoker and let it rest for 10-15 minutes to allow the juices to redistribute within the meat.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Smoked Tri-Tip
Description: Smoked Tri-Tip Steak with Bone Marrow and Bacon Butter is a mouthwatering culinary delight that promises to elevate your grilling game. The tri-tip steak is coated with a tantalizing beef rub, then left to rest and marinate in the refrigerator, allowing the flavors to infuse the meat. In the meantime, bone marrow is slowly cooked to tender perfection, releasing its rich, savory essence. The magic happens when the bone marrow is combined with softened butter and chopped bacon, creating a decadent and flavorful bone marrow and bacon butter. Once the tri-tip is smothered in this luscious butter, it's time to hit the smoker. Slowly smoked at 250°F until the internal temperature reaches a perfect medium-rare, the steak absorbs the smoky goodness, resulting in a tender, juicy, and incredibly flavorful dish. Sliced against the grain and served with complementary sides, this dish is sure to impress with its complexity of flavors and impressive presentation. Prepare to delight in a symphony of taste sensations with every bite of this delectable smoked tri-tip masterpiece.

ingredients.Name: (approx. 900g) chicken wings, separated into drumettes and flats
Vegetable oil, for brushing the grill or flattop
Fresh cilantro leaves and chopped peanuts for garnish (optional)

directions.Direction: Preparing the Thai Peanut Sauce: In a mixing bowl, combine the peanut butter, salt, black pepper, ground ginger, chili paste, brown sugar, soy sauce, and lime juice. Use an immersion blender to blend the ingredients until the sauce is smooth and well combined. If the sauce is too thick, you can add a splash of water to achieve the desired consistency. Set aside.

Preparing the Chicken Wings: Pat dry the chicken wings with paper towels to ensure they are not too moist. This helps achieve a crispy texture during cooking. Season the wings with a pinch of salt and black pepper to taste.
Grilling the Chicken Wings: If using a grill: Preheat your grill to medium-high heat (around 375-400°F). Brush the grates with vegetable oil to prevent sticking.
If using a flattop: Heat the flattop over medium-high heat and lightly grease it with vegetable oil.

Cooking the Chicken Wings: Place the seasoned chicken wings on the grill or flattop. Cook the wings for about 15-20 minutes, turning occasionally, until they are cooked through and have a nice charred and crispy exterior. The exact cooking time may vary depending on the heat of your grill or flattop.

Glazing the Wings: In the last few minutes of grilling, generously brush the Thai peanut sauce on both sides of the wings. Allow the sauce to caramelize slightly and create a flavorful glaze on the wings. Be careful not to let the sauce burn.

Serving: Remove the wings from the grill or flattop and transfer them to a serving plate. If desired, sprinkle fresh cilantro leaves and chopped peanuts over the wings for added flavor and texture. Serve the Thai peanut sauce chicken wings with lime wedges on the side for a zesty kick.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Thai Peanut Sauce Wings
Description: These Thai Peanut Sauce Chicken Wings are an irresistible fusion of bold flavors and tender, juicy meat. The wings, perfectly grilled on an open flame or a sizzling flattop, boast a charred and crispy exterior that promises a satisfying crunch with every bite. As you lift the wings to your mouth, the aroma of smoky goodness inThese Thai Peanut Sauce Chicken Wings are an irresistible fusion of bold flavors and tender, juicy meat. The wings, perfectly grilled on an open flame or a sizzling flattop, boast a charred and crispy exterior that promises a satisfying crunch with every bite. As you lift the wings to your mouth, the aroma of smoky goodness infused with the fragrant notes of ginger and lime tantalizes your senses.fused with the fragrant notes of ginger and lime tantalizes your senses.

directions.Direction: Preparing the Habanero Dragon Toes: Using a sharp knife, carefully cut the tops off the habanero peppers and remove the seeds and membranes, creating a cavity while keeping the bottom intact (the shape should resemble dragon toes). Rinse the peppers under cold water and set them aside.

Stuffing the Habanero Peppers: Place one scallop into each habanero pepper cavity, pressing it firmly inside. Wrap a strip of bacon around each stuffed habanero pepper, securing it in place with toothpicks.
Preparing the Smoker: Preheat your smoker to 275°F.

Smoking the Habanero Dragon Toes: Carefully place the bacon-wrapped habanero peppers on the smoker rack. Let them smoke at 275°F for about an hour or until the bacon is crispy and the scallops are cooked through.

Making the Garlic Parmesan Sauce: In a saucepan over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the minced garlic and cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant, but not browned. Stir in the grated Parmesan cheese and black pepper, allowing the cheese to melt, and blend with the butter and garlic. Pour in the heavy cream, stirring continuously until the sauce thickens and becomes creamy. Adjust the seasoning to taste.

Serving the Spicy Habanero Dragon Toes: Carefully remove the toothpicks from the smoked habanero peppers. Arrange the dragon toes on a serving platter and drizzle the garlic Parmesan sauce over them. Garnish with chopped fresh parsley for added color and flavor.
Serve hot and enjoy the spicy, smoky, and succulent delicacy with the rich and creamy garlic Parmesan sauce to balance the heat.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Spicy Habanero Dragon Toes
Description: Spicy Habanero Dragon Toes with Garlic Parmesan Sauce are a mouthwatering and adventurous appetizer that combines the intense heat of habanero peppers with the delicate sweetness of scallops, all wrapped in smoky bacon. The habaneros are carefully deseeded, leaving the bottom intact, resembling dragon toes, while the succulent scallops are nestled inside, providing a surprising and delicious contrast of flavors and textures. After spending time in the smoker, the bacon becomes crispy, infusing the dish with a delightful smokiness that complements the spiciness of the peppers.

ingredients.Name: bacon strips (enough to wrap the onion rings)
Seasoning rub of your choice (e.g., paprika, garlic powder, onion powder)

directions.Direction: Preheat your grill or oven to 275°F.
Preparing the Beef: In a bowl, mix ground beef, shredded cheddar cheese, salt, and black pepper until well combined.

Preparing the Stuffed Onion Rings: Cut the ends off the onions, peel them, and slice them into thick rings (about 1/2 to 3/4-inch thick). Separate the rings and keep the two largest rings from each onion intact to form the outer layer of the stuffed onion rings. Reserve the rest of the onion for another use.  Take one large onion ring and press a smaller onion ring inside it, forming a larger onion ring with a space in the middle. Fill the inner cavity with the ground beef and cheese mixture, pressing it firmly to form a stuffed onion ring. Take 2-3 bacon strips and wrap them around the stuffed onion ring, securing the filling in place. Repeat this process for the remaining onion rings.
Seasoning the Bacon-Wrapped Onion Rings: Once all the onion rings are stuffed and wrapped with bacon, sprinkle the seasoning rub evenly over each one, coating the bacon.

Cooking the Bacon-Wrapped Stuffed Onion Rings: Place the bacon-wrapped stuffed onion rings on the grill or in the oven on a baking sheet. Cook at 275°F (135°C) for about 2 hours until the bacon is crispy and the meat filling is cooked through. If using a grill, you can use indirect heat to avoid burning the bacon. If using an oven, place the baking sheet on the middle rack.
Preparing the Burger Sauce: In a small mixing bowl, combine mayonnaise, relish, ketchup, sugar, and vinegar. Stir until well combined. Cover the bowl and refrigerate until serving.

Serving: Carefully remove the bacon-wrapped stuffed onion rings from the grill or oven. Serve the bacon-wrapped stuffed onion rings as a delicious and unique appetizer or main dish.  Don't forget to serve the basic burger sauce as a dip on the side for added flavor.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Bacon Burger Onion Rings
Description: Bacon Burger Onion Rings with Burger Sauce are a delightful twist on classic onion rings and burgers. These indulgent treats feature large onion rings stuffed with a mouthwatering mixture of seasoned ground beef and cheddar cheese, topped with a smaller onion ring inside, and then wrapped in crispy bacon. The bacon-wrapped onion rings are coated with a flavorful seasoning rub and slow-baked on a grill or in the oven for two hours, resulting in a deliciously tender and smoky taste. Served alongside a tangy and creamy burger sauce made from mayo, relish, ketchup, sugar, and vinegar, these bacon donuts offer a burst of flavors that will leave everyone craving more.

directions.Direction: Prepare the Ribs: Begin by removing the membrane from the back of the ribs using a knife or your fingers. This helps the seasoning penetrate the meat better and results in more tender ribs. Rinse the ribs under cold water and pat them dry with paper towels.

Create the Flamin' Hot Cheeto Seasoning: Place the Flamin' Hot Cheetos in a resealable plastic bag and crush them into a coarse powder using a rolling pin or a heavy object. You can also use a food processor for this step. Transfer the crushed Cheetos to a bowl and add salt and pepper to taste, adjusting the seasoning according to your preferred level of heat.

Marinate the Ribs: Generously brush both sides of the ribs with hot sauce, using it as a binder for the seasoning. Sprinkle the Flamin' Hot Cheeto seasoning on both sides of the ribs, pressing it gently to adhere.

Preheat the Grill or Smoker: Preheat your grill or smoker to 225°F for indirect cooking. If using charcoal, place the charcoal on one side of the grill and the ribs on the other side to avoid direct heat.
Cook the Ribs: Place the seasoned ribs on the grill or smoker, bone-side down. Cook the ribs at 225°F for approximately 2 hours, or until they reach your desired tenderness.

Wrap the Ribs: Remove the ribs from the grill or smoker and place each rack separately on a large sheet of aluminum foil. Add 2 tablespoons of unsalted butter on top of each rack, add additional seasoning, and drizzle 2 tablespoons of apple cider vinegar over the ribs. Seal the foil tightly around the ribs, creating a packet to trap in the moisture and flavors.
Continue Cooking: Place the foil-wrapped ribs back on the grill or smoker for an additional hour, allowing the flavors to meld and the meat to become even more tender.
Unwrap and Glaze: Carefully open the foil packets and save the liquid inside. Brush the ribs with the liquid from the foil packets to glaze them, giving them a glossy finish.
Final Cooking: Return the unwrapped ribs to the grill or smoker and cook for another 20 minutes to set the glaze.

Serve and Enjoy: Once done, remove the ribs from the grill or smoker and let them rest for a few minutes. Cut the ribs into individual portions and serve with your favorite side dishes. Enjoy the intense heat and bold flavors of these Flamin' Hot Cheeto Ribs!

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Flamin' Hot Cheeto Ribs
Description: Prepare your taste buds for a sizzling adventure with these Flamin' Hot Cheeto Ribs! This finger-licking recipe infuses the deliciously spicy and cheesy flavor of Flamin' Hot Cheetos into succulent ribs. The ribs are first marinated in a fiery hot sauce to lock in moisture and enhance the heat. Then, a homemade seasoning blend crafted from crushed Flamin' Hot Cheetos is generously applied for an explosive taste. Slow-cooked to perfection on the grill or smoker, the ribs are tenderized, wrapped in foil with a delightful mix of butter and apple cider vinegar, and finally, glazed with their own savory juices. Prepare yourself for an unforgettable BBQ experience that brings the heat!

ingredients.Name: Pickled jalapenos, sliced (as per your preference)
sausage meat (pork or any other sausage of your choice)
red chilis, seeded and finely chopped

directions.Direction: Prepare the Parsley-Garlic Sauce: In a food processor or blender, combine the chopped parsley, minced garlic, chopped red chilis, salt, and dried oregano. Pulse the mixture a few times until it forms a coarse paste. Gradually add the red wine vinegar and olive oil while blending until the sauce reaches a smooth consistency. Transfer the sauce to a bowl and set it aside.
Prepare the Sausage Bread: Take each soft bun and slice it in half horizontally. Remove some of the soft bread from the center of each bun half, creating a hollow space.
Assemble the Sausage Bread: Spread a generous amount of cream cheese inside each hollowed bun half. Add pickled jalapeno slices and sprinkle shredded cheddar cheese on top of the cream cheese.
Shape the Sausage Patties: Divide the sausage meat into four equal portions. Flatten each portion into a patty that matches the size of the bun.

Cook the Sausage Patties: Heat a grill or griddle over medium heat. Add a little butter to the cooking surface to prevent sticking. Place the sausage patties on the grill and cook for about 4-5 minutes per side or until they are fully cooked through and have a nicely browned exterior.

Grill the Sausage Bread: In the same griddle or grill, melt some more butter. Place the assembled buns (cream cheese, jalapenos, and cheddar side up) on the griddle. Press a cooked sausage patty onto the cheese and jalapeno layer of each bun. Cook the buns for about 2-3 minutes on each side, pressing down gently with a spatula to create a crispy, golden crust.

Serve the Griddled Sausage Bread: Once the sausage bread is cooked to perfection, remove it from the griddle, and place it on a serving plate. Drizzle the prepared Parsley-Garlic Sauce over the top of each sandwich, adding a burst of fresh flavor and a kick of heat.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Griddled Sausage Bread
Description:
The Griddled Sausage Bread is a flavorful and indulgent sandwich that features a soft bun filled with cream cheese, pickled jalapenos, and shredded cheddar cheese. On top of this cheese and jalapeno layer sits a delicious, flat sausage patty. The entire sandwich is grilled to perfection with butter, creating a crispy crust on the outside while keeping the inside moist and delectable.

The sandwich's similarities to an Argentinian choripan lie in the use of sausage as the main protein and the grilling method. In both dishes, sausage meat takes center stage, bringing a rich and savory taste. Additionally, both sandwiches are often grilled to enhance the flavors and add a pleasant charred element. However, the Griddled Sausage Bread distinguishes itself with the addition of cream cheese and shredded cheddar cheese, providing a creamy and cheesy contrast to the spiciness of the pickled jalapenos and the zesty kick of the Parsley-Garlic Sauce. These unique elements create a delightful fusion of flavors, making it a scrumptious and enjoyable sandwich experience.

directions.Direction: Prepare the Steak: Take the tomahawk steak out of the refrigerator and let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes before cooking. This allows for even cooking throughout the meat.

Season the Steak: Mix the kosher salt, garlic powder, and black pepper in a small bowl. Rub this seasoning blend generously all over the steak, ensuring it's well coated on all sides. Let the seasoned steak rest for an additional 10 minutes to allow the flavors to penetrate the meat.

Set up the Smoker and Campfire: Start your smoker and bring it to a stable temperature of 225°F (107°C). Use your preferred wood chips or chunks for the smoke flavor; mesquite, hickory, or oak work well with beef. While the smoker is heating up, build a campfire nearby. You'll use the campfire later for searing the steak.

Smoke the Steak: Once the smoker is at the desired temperature, place the seasoned tomahawk steak on the smoker's grate, away from direct heat. Smoke the steak until its internal temperature reaches around 115°F. Use a reliable meat thermometer to monitor the temperature. This slow-smoking process will infuse the steak with delicious smoky flavors.

Prepare the Garlic Butter: While the steak is smoking, prepare the garlic butter. In a small bowl, combine the softened butter with the minced garlic. Mix well until the garlic is evenly distributed throughout the butter.

Sear the Steak: Once the internal temperature of the steak reaches 115°F, carefully move the steak from the smoker to a grill grate positioned over the open flames of the campfire. Sear the steak for about 1 to 2 minutes per side, or until a beautiful crust forms on the surface. Keep a close eye on the steak to avoid overcooking.

Apply Garlic Butter: Remove the seared steak from the campfire and place it on a clean cutting board. Allow it to rest for a few minutes. While resting, slice a few knobs of the garlic butter and place them on top of the hot steak. Allow the butter to melt and infuse the meat with its rich, savory flavor.
Serve and Enjoy: Slice the smoked and seared tomahawk steak into thick, juicy portions and serve it immediately.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Campfire Tomahawk Steak with Garlic Butter
Description: Prepare yourself for an unforgettable dining experience with this thick and juicy tomahawk steak, masterfully cooked over a smoker and a campfire. The combination of slow-smoking and searing creates a mouthwatering crust on the outside while retaining a tender, perfectly cooked interior. Seasoned with a classic blend of salt, garlic powder, and pepper, this steak is taken to the next level by finishing it off with luscious garlic butter knobs.

directions.Direction: Cook the Pasta: Boil the conchiglie pasta in salted water until al dente according to the package instructions. Once cooked, drain the pasta and rinse it with cold water to stop the cooking process. Place the pasta in the fridge to cool.
Brown the Sausage: Cook the sausage in a large pan until lightly browned. Save the juices by straining the meat over a large bowl once cooked. Set it aside and save for later.
Smoke the Queso: Preheat your smoker to 250°F. In a heat-resistant pan or aluminum foil pan, combine the diced tomatoes, Velveeta cheese, pickled jalapenos, and browned sausage.

Smoke the Queso Mixture: Place the pan with the queso mixture in the preheated smoker. Smoke it for 2 hours, stirring the mixture halfway through to ensure even smoke distribution and melting of the cheese.

Prepare the Sauce: In a saucepan, combine the saved sausage juices, mayonnaise, cornstarch, cayenne pepper, black pepper, paprika, and garlic powder. Stir well over medium heat until the sauce thickens and becomes smooth. Adjust the seasoning to your taste.

Stuff the Pasta Shells: Remove the smoked queso mixture from the smoker and let it cool slightly. Using a spoon, carefully fill each conchiglie pasta shell with the smoked queso mixture, making sure to distribute it evenly among all the shells.

Finish in the Oven: Preheat your oven to 350°F. Place the filled pasta shells in a baking dish, and then bake them for an additional hour until the filling is heated through and the pasta is slightly browned and crispy on top.
Serve and Enjoy: Once the pasta shells are done baking, remove them from the oven and drizzle the prepared sauce over the top. Garnish with additional diced tomatoes or fresh herbs if desired.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Smoked Queso Pasta Shells
Description: Smoked Queso Pasta Shells are a delightful fusion of smoky flavors, creamy cheese, and spicy sausage, all stuffed inside tender conchiglie pasta shells. This indulgent dish is perfect for those who crave a cheesy, flavorful, and slightly spicy pasta experience. The combination of smoked queso and the rich sauce elevates the dish to a whole new level of deliciousness. It's the perfect comfort food for gatherings or a satisfying weeknight dinner.

ingredients.Name: fresh ears of corn, husks removed
Takis chips, crushed into fine crumbs
cayenne pepper (adjust according to your spice preference)
Tabasco sauce (adjust to your desired spiciness)
Mexican seasoning blend (can include a mix of chili powder, cumin, paprika, and oregano))

directions.Direction: Preheat your smoker to 350°F or preheat your oven to 350°F if you don't have a smoker.
In a bowl, mix the crushed Takis chips, smoked paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, cayenne pepper, salt, and pepper. This will create the Taki chips flavored seasoning.
Dip each ear of corn into water to moisten the surface slightly.
Roll the moistened corn ears in the Takis chips seasoning mixture, pressing the crumbs gently onto the corn to adhere.
If using a smoker, place the Takis coated corn directly on the grates. If using an oven, you can either place the corn on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or wrap each ear in aluminum foil.
Cook the corn for approximately 30 minutes or until the corn is tender and the Takis coating becomes crispy and golden.

While the corn is cooking, prepare the sauce. In a small bowl, whisk together the sour cream, mayonnaise, Tabasco sauce, chili powder, and crushed chili flakes until well combined. Adjust the spiciness and seasoning to suit your taste.
Once the corn is done, remove it from the smoker or oven and let it cool slightly.
Generously coat each ear of corn with the prepared sauce.
Sprinkle the crumbled feta cheese over the sauced corn.
Finally, sprinkle the Mexican seasoning blend over the top of the corn for an extra burst of flavor.
Serve the Takis Coated Street Corn while it's still warm, and enjoy the unique and delicious combination of flavors!

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Takis Street Corn
Description: This recipe combines the smoky flavors from the smoker or oven with the crunchy and spicy elements of Takis chips, all complemented by the tangy and spicy sauce and the creaminess of feta cheese.

ingredients.Name: pork belly, skin removed and cut into bite sized pieces

directions.Direction: Preparing the Pork Belly Bites: Start by preheating your smoker to 250°F (120°C). If your smoker requires water, fill the water pan accordingly.

Coating the Pork Belly Bites: Place the pork belly bites on a wire rack for easy smoking. This will allow the smoke to surround the meat evenly. In a large bowl, combine the Honey Mustard IPA rub with the pork belly bites. Toss and rub the seasoning thoroughly to coat each piece evenly.

Smoking the Pork Belly Bites: Once the smoker is at the desired temperature, place the wire rack with the seasoned pork belly bites inside the smoker. Smoke the pork belly bites at 250°F (120°C) for approximately 2 hours.

Spraying with Apple Cider Vinegar: After the first hour of smoking, carefully open the smoker and spray the pork belly bites with apple cider vinegar. This will help keep them moist and add a tangy flavor to the meat. Close the smoker and continue smoking for the remaining time.

Preparing the Honey and Butter Glaze: While the pork belly bites are smoking, prepare the glaze. In a small saucepan, melt the butter over low heat. Add the honey to the melted butter and stir until well combined. Keep the glaze warm until ready to use.

Applying the Honey and Butter Glaze: After the initial 2 hours of smoking, remove the pork belly bites from the smoker and transfer them to a deep tray or aluminum foil tray. Pour the honey and butter glaze over the pork belly bites, ensuring they are coated evenly.

Smoking for the Final Hour: Cover the tray tightly with aluminum foil or use a lid if your tray has one. Place the tray back into the smoker and continue smoking at 250°F (120°C) for another hour. This step will allow the glaze to caramelize and intensify the flavors.
Serving: Once the pork belly bites are done, remove them from the smoker. Serve hot as a delicious appetizer or main dish. These bites pair well with coleslaw, pickles, or a refreshing side salad.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Flavor Bombs - Pork Belly Bites
Description: These mouthwatering pork belly bites are the perfect combination of smoky, sweet, and tangy flavors. Coated in a delicious honey mustard IPA rub from Spiceology, they are smoked to perfection at a low temperature, resulting in tender, juicy, and flavorful bites. The finishing touch of honey and butter glaze adds a sticky caramelized coating, making these pork belly bites an irresistible treat for any BBQ or gathering.

ingredients.Name: chicken, spine removed and chest bone crushed flat

directions.Direction: Prepare the injection mixture: In a blender, combine olive oil, garlic cloves, lemon juice, lemon zest, thyme, oregano, rosemary, parsley, salt, and black pepper. Blend until you have a smooth, fragrant marinade.

Debone the chicken: Carefully remove the spine from the chicken using sharp kitchen shears or a knife. Then, gently crush the chest bone to flatten the chicken, ensuring even cooking and better infusion of flavors.

Inject the chicken: Using a meat injector, inject the marinade into various parts of the chicken, such as the breasts, thighs, and drumsticks. This will help to infuse the meat with the rich Mediterranean flavors.
Coat the chicken: Pour the remaining marinade over the chicken, making sure to cover both sides evenly. Massage the marinade into the skin, ensuring it adheres to the meat.
Apply the Greek rub: Sprinkle a generous amount of the Greek rub over the chicken, creating a tantalizing outer crust that will complement the injected flavors.
Preheat the smoker: Prepare your smoker and preheat it to a temperature of 225°F.

Smoke the chicken: Once the smoker is ready, place the chicken on the grill grates and let it smoke for about 4 hours or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F. Periodically check the temperature and add more wood chips if needed to maintain the smoke.
Rest and serve: Once the chicken is fully cooked, remove it from the smoker and let it rest for a few minutes before carving.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Greek God Injected Chicken
Description: Prepare to elevate your taste buds to heavenly heights with this succulent and flavorful Greek God-Injected Chicken! This culinary masterpiece begins with a whole chicken, carefully deboned to allow for even cooking and easy carving. The chest bone is gently crushed to create a flat surface, ensuring that every inch of this divine bird is infused with the mouthwatering flavors of the Mediterranean.

ingredients.Name: sweet mini peppers, halved and cored (seeds removed)

directions.Direction: Prepare the peppers: Slice the mini peppers in half lengthwise and carefully remove the seeds and membranes. Rinse them under cold water and pat dry with a paper towel. Set aside.

Prepare the goat cheese: In a mixing bowl, soften the goat cheese to room temperature. You can do this by leaving it out for about 30 minutes or microwaving it for a few seconds on low power. Using a spoon or a piping bag, fill each pepper half with the softened goat cheese, smoothing the top for an even finish.

Wrap the peppers: Take a slice of prosciutto and cut it lengthwise into two thinner strips. Carefully wrap each goat cheese-filled pepper half with one strip of prosciutto, securing it gently around the pepper.

Smoking in the smoker or oven: Preheat your smoker or oven to 250°F. If using a smoker, add your preferred wood chips for added flavor. Place the wrapped pepper poppers on a smoking rack or baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
Smoking time: Smoke the poppers for approximately 1 hour, or until the prosciutto becomes crispy and slightly caramelized. The goat cheese should also become soft and warm.

Glazing with red pepper jelly: Remove the pepper poppers from the smoker or oven. Using a brush or spoon, generously coat each popper with the red pepper jelly, covering the prosciutto and goat cheese.
Final smoking: Return the jelly-glazed pepper poppers to the smoker or oven for an additional 20 minutes. This step helps caramelize the jelly and adds a delicious sweet and spicy glaze to the dish.
Serve and enjoy: Remove the goat cheese pepper poppers from the smoker or oven, and let them cool for a couple of minutes.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Goat Cheese Pepper Poppers
Description: Introducing our delightful Goat Cheese Pepper Poppers, a delectable alternative to the classic jalapeño poppers! Made with sweet mini peppers, these poppers offer a unique twist on the traditional recipe, perfect for those who prefer a milder yet equally flavorful option.

directions.Direction: Prepare the smoker: Preheat your smoker to 225°F using your choice of wood chips for smoking. If you don't have a smoker, you can use a grill with indirect heat and a smoking box.

Smoke the onions: Spread the thinly sliced onions on a perforated pan or foil pan suitable for the smoker. Smoke the onions at 225°F for 5 hours, stirring them gently every hour to ensure even smoking and caramelization. The onions should have a rich golden-brown color and a smoky aroma when done.
Prepare the soup base: In a large pot or Dutch oven, melt the butter over medium heat. Add the smoked onions and sauté them for a few minutes until they further caramelize and become tender.
Season the base: Add the garlic powder, sugar, black pepper, salt, and MSG (if using). Stir well to combine and let the flavors meld for a couple of minutes.
Deglaze with white wine: Pour in the dry white wine and scrape any browned bits from the bottom of the pot. Allow the wine to simmer and reduce slightly, enhancing the flavors of the soup base.

Add beef stock and herbs: Pour in the beef stock and drop in the fresh thyme, rosemary sprigs, and bay leaves. Bring the soup to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for about 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld together.

Assemble and serve: Place a splash of balsamic vinegar at the bottom of each soup bowl. Ladle the hot smoked French onion soup over the vinegar. Place a handful of croutons on the top of the soup and cover with provolone cheese.
Broil: Carefully place the soup bowls under the broiler until the provolone cheese is bubbly and slightly golden.
Serve hot: Remove the bowls from the broiler and let them cool slightly before serving. The smoked French onion soup is now ready to enjoy!

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Smoked French Onion Soup
Description: Smoked French Onion Soup is a delightful twist on the classic French onion soup, where the rich flavors of caramelized onions are infused with a subtle smokiness, creating a soul-warming and comforting dish. The onions are slow-smoked to perfection, enhancing their natural sweetness and adding a depth of flavor. This soup is then paired with large croutons and melted provolone cheese, creating a satisfying and indulgent dining experience.

directions.Direction: Prepare the brine: In a large container or resealable plastic bag, combine water, salt, sugar, crushed garlic, and bay leaves. Stir well until the salt and sugar dissolve completely.

Prep the chicken: Remove the bones and skin from the chicken leaving the skin intact. Chop the chicken into small pieces, about 1-inch in size. Season the chopped chicken generously with your rub of choice.

Wrap the chicken in the skin: Take the seasoned chicken and wrap the skin around it, creating a neat package. Use butcher's twine to tie the wrapped chicken tightly, ensuring it holds its shape during cooking.
Brine the chicken: Place the tied chicken pieces in the brine, making sure they are fully submerged. Seal the container or bag and refrigerate overnight (at least 8 hours).
Remove from brine and pat dry: The next day, take the chicken out of the brine and pat it dry using paper towels. Discard the brine.
Season again: Season the chicken once more with your rub, adjusting the seasoning to your taste preferences.

Oven method: Preheat your oven to 400°F. Place the seasoned chicken on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or in a baking dish. Roast the chicken in the preheated oven for about 50 minutes or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F when tested with a meat thermometer.

Air fryer method: Preheat your air fryer to 400°F. Lightly brush the air fryer basket with olive oil to prevent sticking. Place the seasoned chicken in the air fryer basket, ensuring they are not touching each other to allow proper airflow.
Airfry the chicken for about 25-30 minutes, turning them halfway through for even cooking, or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (75°C).
Serve and enjoy: Once cooked, let the chicken rest for a few minutes before slicing and serving. The crispy skin and tender, juicy meat will be a feast for your senses.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Boneless Chopped Chicken Stuffed in Chicken Skin
Description: This delectable boneless chicken recipe takes chicken to a whole new level by removing the bones and skin, but keeping the skin intact to wrap around the seasoned, chopped chicken pieces. Brining the chicken with garlic and bay leaves adds a wonderful depth of flavor, making it moist and succulent. Once you take the first bite of this tender, juicy, and perfectly seasoned chicken, you'll be amazed by the explosion of flavors.

ingredients.Name: roasted garlic hot sauce (adjust to taste)

directions.Direction: Smoke the Flour and Panko: Preheat your smoker to around 150°F. On one half of a baking sheet add flour on the other half add panko crumbs. Place the baking sheet in the smoker and smoke the flour and panko for 1-2 hours, stirring occasionally. Remove the smoked flour and panko from the smoker and set aside.

Hard-Boil the Eggs: Place the eggs in a saucepan and cover them with water. Bring the water to a boil, then reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Cook the eggs for 10-12 minutes. Remove from heat and place the eggs in an ice water bath to cool completely. Once cooled, carefully peel the eggs and cut them in half lengthwise. Remove the yolks and set aside.

Prepare the Filling: In a food processor, combine the egg yolks, mayonnaise, roasted garlic hot sauce, grainy mustard, black pepper, salt, and lemon juice. Process the mixture until smooth and creamy. Adjust the seasoning to taste if needed.

Coat the Egg Whites: In a shallow bowl whisk one egg and dunk each egg white until coated. Cover the egg white with smoked flour then smoked panko crumbs pressing gently to ensure it adheres to the egg white surface.

Deep Fry the Deviled Egg Halves: In a deep skillet or frying pan, heat enough cooking oil (beef fat recommended for added flavor) to about 350°F (175°C). Carefully place the coated egg whites in the hot oil, a few at a time, and fry until they turn golden brown and crispy. It should take around 2-3 minutes per batch. Use a slotted spoon to remove the fried egg whites and place them on a plate lined with paper towels to drain any excess oil.

Assemble and Garnish: Once all the egg white halves are fried, fill each half with the prepared filling using a spoon or a piping bag for a neater presentation. Garnish the deviled eggs with small pieces of prosciutto and chopped fresh chives.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Breaded Deviled Eggs
Description: Serve your Smoked and Deep-Fried Deviled Eggs as a delightful appetizer or party snack. The combination of the smoky flavor, creamy filling, and crispy coating will surely impress.

directions.Direction: Prepare the asparagus: Break the tough ends of the asparagus and grill them for 1-2 minutes until bright green.
Cream cheese filling: In a small bowl, mix the softened cream cheese with a pinch of salt and black pepper until well combined.

Assemble the rolls: Lay out the prosciutto slices on a clean surface. Spread a thin layer of the cream cheese mixture over each slice of prosciutto. Place 3-5 asparagus spears at one end of the prosciutto and gently roll them up to encase the asparagus.

Prepare the flank steak: Lay them out flat and place one prosciutto-wrapped bundle of asparagus on each flank steak slice. Roll the flank steak around the prosciutto and asparagus bundle, securing it with kitchen twine

Cook the asparagus rolls: Heat the olive oil in a skillet or grill pan over medium-high heat. Add the flank steak-wrapped asparagus rolls and cook for about 3-4 minutes per side, or until the steak is cooked to your desired doneness and the asparagus is tender-crisp.
Serve: Remove the kitchen twine before serving. You can slice the rolls into smaller pieces for bite-sized portions or serve them whole. q

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Steak Wrapped Asparagus
Description: Asparagus wrapped in prosciutto and cream cheese, then encased in tender flank steak makes for a mouthwatering dish

ingredients.Name: MSG (optional but enhances the umami flavor)

directions.Direction: Marinate the Chicken: Pour the buttermilk over the chicken pieces in a large mixing bowl. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let the chicken marinate in the buttermilk for at least 2 hours (overnight is even better).

Smoke the Flour: Start by preheating your smoker to a low temperature (around 150°F). Spread the all-purpose flour in a thin, even layer on a shallow baking sheet. Smoke the flour for 3-4 hours, stirring occasionally to ensure even smoking. The flour should develop a light, smoky aroma.
Remove the smoked flour from the smoker and let it cool completely before using it for dredging the chicken.

Prepare the Smoked Flour Mixture: In a separate mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, ground black pepper, garlic powder, salt, MSG (if using), and dried parsley. Mix well until all the spices are evenly incorporated into the flour.

Dredging Process: Preheat the vegetable oil in a large, deep frying pan or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Take one piece of marinated chicken and dredge it in the smoked flour mixture, ensuring it is fully coated on all sides. Shake off any excess flour. Dip the flour-coated chicken back into the buttermilk, coating it once again.
Place the double-dredged chicken on a wire rack while you repeat the process with the remaining chicken pieces.
Fry the Chicken: Carefully place the double-dredged chicken pieces into the hot oil, being cautious not to overcrowd the pan. Fry the chicken in batches if necessary.
Fry the chicken until it reaches a deep golden brown color and is fully cooked through. The internal temperature should read 165°F (74°C) for safety.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Smoked Flour Fried Chicken
Description: Buttermilk fried chicken with a twist

ingredients.Name: large jalapenos, cored and seeds removed
spice rub (your favorite blend or store bought)
ground sausage (spicy or mild, depending on your preference)
hot honey (store bought or make your own by mixing honey with a touch of chili flakes or hot sauce)

directions.Direction: Prepare the jalapenos: Cut the tops off the jalapenos, then carefully core them and remove the seeds. Wear gloves to avoid contact with the spicy oils.
Make the cream cheese filling: In a bowl, mix the softened cream cheese and shredded cheddar until well combined. Add some of the spice rub to the mixture if you want an extra kick of flavor.
Stuff the jalapenos: Fill each cored jalapeno with the cream cheese and cheddar mixture, packing it tightly to ensure they are well-stuffed.

Wrap in sausage: Take a handful of the ground sausage and flatten it into a thin patty. Place a stuffed jalapeno in the center and gently wrap the sausage around it, covering the entire jalapeno. Repeat this process for all the jalapenos.
Bacon wrapping: Wrap each sausage-covered jalapeno with a slice of bacon, securing it with toothpicks if necessary.
Preheat the smoker: Preheat your smoker to 250°F (121°C) with your choice of smoking wood for flavor.
Smoke the armadillo eggs: Place the wrapped and stuffed jalapenos on the smoker rack and smoke them for about 1 hour. The bacon should become crispy, and the sausage should cook through.
Glaze with hot honey: After the first hour of smoking, brush each armadillo egg with the hot honey glaze, coating them generously.

Continue smoking: Return the glazed armadillo eggs to the smoker and continue smoking for another hour. This will allow the flavors to meld, and the hot honey glaze will caramelize, adding a perfect sweet and spicy finish.
Serve and enjoy: Carefully remove the armadillo eggs from the smoker and let them cool slightly before serving.

ingredients.Name: 1 beef brisket (approximately  pounds), with a nice fat cap

directions.Direction: Trim the Brisket: Remove any excessive fat and silver skin from the brisket, leaving a thin layer of fat on the top side. This will allow the rub to penetrate the meat properly.
Prepare the Rub: In a bowl, combine the coarse kosher salt and black pepper. Mix well to create the salt and pepper rub.

Apply the Rub: Generously apply the salt and pepper rub all over the brisket, making sure to coat all sides evenly. Use your hands to press the rub into the meat, allowing it to adhere well. Let the seasoned brisket sit at room temperature for about 1 hour before smoking.
Preheat the Smoker: Prepare your smoker and preheat it to 225°F (107°C). Use oak or hickory wood chunks/chips for a traditional Texas-style smoky flavor.

Smoke the Brisket: Place the seasoned brisket on the smoker grates, fat-side up. Close the smoker and maintain a steady temperature of 225°F (107°C). Smoke the brisket until it reaches an internal temperature of about 160°F (71°C). This can take around 5 to 7 hours depending on the size of the brisket and your smoker's efficiency.

Wrap in Butcher Paper: Once the brisket reaches an internal temperature of 160°F (71°C), remove it from the smoker and cover it in rendered brisket fat, wrap it tightly in unwaxed butcher paper. The butcher paper allows the brisket to breathe while maintaining moisture. Return the wrapped brisket to the smoker, fat-side up.

Continue Smoking: Close the smoker and continue cooking until the brisket reaches an internal temperature of around 200-205°F (93-96°C). The total cooking time can take anywhere from 12 to 16 hours, depending on the size and thickness of the brisket.

Rest and Slice: Once the brisket reaches the desired internal temperature, remove it from the smoker and let it rest, still wrapped in the butcher paper, for about 1 hour. This resting period allows the juices to redistribute throughout the meat, making it juicier and more tender. After resting, carefully unwrap the brisket and slice it against the grain to serve.
Serve and Enjoy: Serve the juicy and flavorful Texas-style smoked brisket with your favorite barbecue sauce or on its own.

Creator: jortskitchen
Name: Juicy Texas Style Brisket
Description: Brisket is a popular and flavorful cut of beef, known for its rich marbling and tenderness when cooked properly. It comes from the lower chest of the cow and is composed of two distinct muscles: the flat, which is lean and even in thickness, and the point, which is fattier and more marbled. This combination of lean and fatty portions makes brisket ideal for slow cooking methods, like smoking, which allows the collagen-rich meat to break down and become tender and juicy. It is a staple in traditional Texas barbecue and is often seasoned with a simple salt and pepper rub to highlight the natural beefy flavor.

directions.Direction: Stuffing the Cannelloni Shells: Preheat your smoker to 225°F (107°C). Carefully stuff each cannelloni shell with a chunk of mozzarella then stuff each of the ends with sausage
Wrapping with Bacon: Take a slice of bacon and wrap it around each stuffed cannelloni shell. The bacon will hold the shell together during the smoking process and add extra flavor.

Smoking the Cannelloni: Place the bacon-wrapped cannelloni on a smoker rack or a grill pan, making sure there's some space between each shell to allow the smoke to circulate. Smoke the cannelloni at 225°F for approximately 1 hour. The bacon should become crisp, and the filling should be fully cooked and oozy.
Coating with BBQ Sauce: Remove the smoked cannelloni from the smoker. Generously brush each bacon-wrapped shell with your favorite BBQ sauce, ensuring they are evenly coated.

Finishing the Smoking Process: Increase the smoker temperature to 275°F. Place the BBQ sauce-coated cannelloni back in the smoker and smoke for an additional hour. This will further infuse the BBQ flavor and give the bacon a beautiful glaze.

Serving: Carefully remove the smoked bacon-wrapped mozzarella stuffed cannelloni from the smoker and let them rest for a few minutes. Serve hot and enjoy the delightful combination of smoky bacon, gooey mozzarella, savory sausage, and sweet BBQ sauce.
